newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: PRESS DIGEST - Ivory Coast - Nov 18.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ivory Coast - Nov 18.

text.p: These are significant items in the Ivorian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these items and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Advertisement from the African Development Bank (AfDB) invites tenders for satellite earth station for its Abidjan headquarters for international communications and possibly regional communications at a later date. Tender open to companies from AfDB or African Development Fund states. Details from the Director of Administrative Services +225 20 40 30 (Tel) 21 64 28 (Fax). Deadline for submissions January 15 1997.
- Three bandits shot dead, 10 drug traffickers arrested over the weekend during series of police raids as part of crackdown on violent crime.

- Soldiers accused of plotting a coup during Ivory Coast's October 1995 presidential election "tried" by secret disciplinary tribunal between November 5 and 8. Tribunal's report to be passed to President Henri Konan Bedie. One of the defendants protests innocence in interview with the opposition Ivorian Popular Front newspaper and demands proper hearing. A total of 18 soldiers were arrested over the affair.

- Africa Sports are Ivory Coast's national soccer league champions winning a berth in African Champions Cup. Army team SOA (Societe Omnisport de l'Armee) to represent Ivory Coast in the Africa Cup Winners Cup; Stade d'Abidjan in the Confederation of African Football Cup.

- A total of 1.2 million people visited Ivory Coast's Expo-CI 96 trade fair which ended Sunday after 10 days; 500 exhibitors took part including companies from West Africa, North Africa, Egypt, China, South Korea, Brazil, France and Spain.

- Ivory Coast's rubber sector expands with 50,000 hectares under cultivation producing 75,000 tonnes a year for six processing exporters, the chairman of the producers association Yves Roland says in an advertising interview. Roland is chairman and managing director of rubber producer SAPH.
